title: 107_s1581
content: The "American Security Enhancement Investment Act of 2001" includes a business deduction for the purchase and installation of qualifying security enhancement property under section 179B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A taxpayer can deduct the cost of qualifying security enhancement property as an expense in the year it is placed in service. Qualifying property must be acquired by purchase, installed in a building owned or occupied by the taxpayer in the United States, and subject to section 168. The term 'security enhancement property' refers to property designed to detect or prevent unlawful access, bringing of harmful items, or protect occupants from harm. The term 'security enhancement property' includes security devices such as electronic access control systems, biometric identification devices, surveillance cameras, and locks for doors and windows. The term 'security enhancement property' includes devices like tumbler, key, coded devices, computers, software for cyberterrorism, electronic alarm systems, and building structures used for commercial purposes. Deductions are allowed for the purchase of qualifying security devices, reducing the basis of the device by the deduction amount. Only the incremental cost of the specific security function described is considered. Similar rules to Section 179 apply. Section 263(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow deductions for expenditures under section 179B, with corresponding changes to sections 312(k)(3)(B) and 1016(a). The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow deductions for expenditures under section 179B, with corresponding changes to sections 312(k)(3)(B) and 1016(a). Section 1245(a) is also amended to include references to section 179B. The amendments made by this section allow deductions for security enhancement property placed in service after September 10, 2001, in taxable years ending after that date.
